#Text=SQL Query Optimization — How to Determine When and If It’s Needed
#Text=It’s easy to start tinkering with the gears of SQL query optimization.

column1: #Text=You open up SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS), monitor wait time, review the execution plan, gather object information and begin optimizing SQL until you’re running a finely tuned machine.
#Text=If you’re good enough at it, you score a quick victory and get back to your regularly scheduled chaos.
#Text=But if you adjust the wrong thing, or adjust the right thing in the wrong direction, well, there went your Wednesday.
#Text=What makes you think you need it?
#Text=Most of the time, it’s a spike in trouble tickets or user complaints.
#Text=“It’s taking us forever to run our usual reports this week.”
#Text=That’s a pretty vague description, of course.
#Text=It would be nice if they could tell you, “Things are slow because you’ve got an implicit conversion in line 62 of CurrentOrderQuery5.sql.
#Text=The column is varchar and you’re passing in an integer.”
#Text=But it’s not likely that your users can see that level of detail.
#Text=At least trouble tickets and phone calls make for an active metric: easy to spot, easy to measure.
#Text=When they start rolling in, you can be reasonably sure that it’s time for SQL tuning.
#Text=But there are other, passive metrics that make the need less clear.
#Text=Things like slumping sales, which could be due to any number of factors.
#Text=Is it because painfully slow queries in your online store are making your customers abandon their shopping carts?
#Text=Is it because the economy is in bad shape?
#Text=Or it could be things like sluggish SQL Server performance.
#Text=Is it because a poorly written query is sending logical reads through the roof?
#Text=Is it because the server is low on physical resources like memory and storage?
#Text=In both scenarios, SQL query optimization can help with the first option, but not the second.
#Text=Why apply the right solution to the wrong problem?
#Text=Before you go down the path of optimization, make sure that tuning is the right solution to the right problem.
#Text=Tuning SQL is a technical process, but every technical step has roots in good business sense.
#Text=You could spend days trying to shorten execution time by a few milliseconds or reduce the number of logical reads by five percent, but is the reduction worth your time?
#Text=It’s true that it’s important to meet the requirements of users, but every effort reaches the point of diminishing returns eventually.
#Text=Consider these SQL query performance problems and the business context around them:
#Text=Acceptable performance — A query takes 10 minutes to run and the user wants it to run in one minute; that seems like a reasonable disparity and an achievable goal for optimization.
#Text=However, if the query takes overnight and the user thinks it should run in one minute, then it may be more than a tuning problem.
#Text=For one thing, you may have to educate the user about the amount of work the query is actually performing.
#Text=For another, it may be a problem with the way the database was designed or the way the client application was written.
#Text=Utility — Suppose you’re responsible for administering the financial database in a manufacturing company.
#Text=At the end of every month, users complain about poor performance.
#Text=You trace the problem to a series of month-end reports run by Accounting that take hours each and go straight into a filing cabinet unexamined by anybody.
#Text=Instead of tuning, you explain the problem to the business managers and obtain permission to delete the reports.
#Text=Time shifting — Or, suppose those same reports are important for governance but not urgent for the business.
#Text=If they are run once per week or per month, they can be scheduled for off-peak hours by pre-caching the data set and sending the results to a file.
#Text=That removes the bottleneck on the other business users and frees the Accounting user from having to wait for the reports.
#Text=When you factor business context into your decision to optimize, you can set priorities and buy yourself time.
#Text=When you do optimize SQL queries, try SQL diagramming
#Text=SSMS and the tools built into SQL Server offer most of what you need for effective SQL query optimization.
#Text=Combine the tools with a methodical approach around the following steps, as described in the e-book The Fundamental Guide to SQL Query Optimization:
#Text=In step 4, your goal is to drive the query with the table that returns the least data.
#Text=When you study joins and predicates, and filter earlier in the query rather than later, you reduce the number of logical reads.
#Text=That’s a big step in SQL query optimization.
#Text=SQL diagramming is a graphical technique for mapping the amount of data in the tables and finding which filter will return the fewest records.
#Text=First, you determine which tables contain the detailed information and which tables are the master or lookup tables.
#Text=Consider the simple example of this query against a university registration database:
#Text=It has two lookup tables, student and class.
#Text=To diagram these tables, draw an upside-down tree connecting the detail table (at the top) with arrows (or links) to the lookup tables, like this:
#Text=Now, calculate the relative number of records required for the join criteria (that is, the average ratio of rows related between the detail table and lookup tables).
#Text=Write the numbers at each end of the arrow.
#Text=In this example, for every student there are about 5 records in the registration table, and for every class there are about 30 records in registration.
#Text=That means it should never be necessary to JOIN more than 150 (5×30) records to get a result for any single student or any single class.
#Text=That exercise is useful if your join columns are not indexed, or if you’re not sure that they’re indexed.
#Text=Next, look at the filtering predicates to find which table to drive the query with.
#Text=This query had two filters: one on registration cancelled = 'N' and the other on signup_date between two dates.
#Text=To see how selective the filter is, run this query on registration:
#Text=It returns 4,344 records out of the 79,800 total records in registration.
#Text=That is, 5.43 percent of the records will be read with that filter.
#Text=It returns two records out of 1,000, or 0.2 percent, which represents a much more selective filter.
#Text=Thus, class is the driving table, and the one on which to focus your SQL tuning first.
#Text=If you’re sure you need SQL tuning, The Fundamental Guide to SQL Query Optimization offers further insight.
#Text=It walks you through five performance tuning tips with copy-and-paste queries and case studies, including the one described above.
#Text=You’ll probably find that the single most important SQL query optimization tool is the voice of the user.
#Text=Because that voice lets you know when to start optimizing and it tells you when you have optimized enough.
#Text=It can ensure that you start tinkering with the gears when you need to and stop while you’re still ahead.
#Text=The Fundamental Guide to SQL Query OptimizationSQL query optimization may be the best part of your job as a database professional.
#Text=You roll up your sleeves, you get analytical, you poke around in code and you measure the impact of your changes.
#Text=This e-book walks you methodically through five basic steps in the SQL tuning process.
#Text=Learn how and what to measure both before and after you’ve made changes so you’re not wasting effort on things that don’t matter.
#Text=Discover how to find and correct common mistakes that eat into SQL query performance.
